s.text: It's a judgment call about whether readers will find having to scroll more annoying than having to click and wait.)

The contents of a Web site are stored on high-performance computers called servers . When you type a Web address into your browser, or click on a link or a "favorites" or "bookmark" button, you are telling your computer to fetch a specific set of data--text, images, sound, etc.--from some Web site's server.

The contents of a Web site are stored on high-performance computers called servers . When you type a Web address into your browser, or click on a link or a "favorites" or "bookmark" button, you are telling your computer to fetch a specific set of data--text, images, sound, etc.--from some Web site's server.
The more separate elements it contains (images, sound ...)
All this caching means pages are served more quickly, but it does become harder for a Web site to know how often its pages have actually appeared on someone's screen.
Every Friday, 20,000 people get a print-out version of Slate delivered to them by e-mail.
Print publications have no clear idea of how many people read each copy of their publication and, conversely, how many individual pages of any given copy go unread.
Print publications have no clear idea of how many people read each copy of their publication and, conversely, how many individual pages of any given copy go unread.

Print publications have no clear idea of how many people read each copy of their publication and, conversely, how many individual pages of any given copy go unread.
Print publications have no clear idea of how many people read each copy of their publication and, conversely, how many individual pages of any given copy go unread.
Traditional print magazines know exactly how many copies they sell, though they have no idea how many people actually read a particular article or see a particular ad.

The contents of a Web site are stored on high-performance computers called servers . When you type a Web address into your browser, or click on a link or a "favorites" or "bookmark" button, you are telling your computer to fetch a specific set of data--text, images, sound, etc.--from some Web site's server.
Each of these requests for information is a hit.

A single Web page can be one hit or many, depending on how it is constructed.

But for a variety of reasons, including caching, IP addresses aren't a great way of counting individual visitors.
are the most common measure of Web traffic.
